Definition.Title: Introduction: Living and Non-living Things 1
Definition.TextTemplate:
**Isn’t our planet a wonderful place? **

There are so many different **@@228B22@living things@@** out there - from the mighty **@@00a6d5@whale@@** to the humble **@@7C0BAE@worm,@@** from the fantastic **@@00a6d5@toadstool@@** to the tiniest @@7C0BAE@**bacterium! **@@

Try and think of **all** of the living things that you know about. You’ll be thinking for a very@@228B22@** long time! **@@

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1498799237.839331f/1498799250422-122578452313106.gif" width="480" height="270"]

Definition.Title: MCQ: Life Processes 1
Definition.TextTemplate:
Which of the following processes is **@@7C0BAE@NOT**@@ required for something to be classified as @@0066cc@**living?**@@ 

[multichoice id="MultiChoice_1"]

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/French/1423521288.93471g/1423521331097-581409109.png" width="300" height="229"]
Definition.ExplanationTemplate:
There are **eight** things that something must carry out to be classified as alive. These are:

[table border="no"
| Movement 
=
| Respiration 
=
| Sensitivity 
=
| Cells
=
| Growth 
=
| Reproduction 
=
| Excretion 
=
| Nutrition 
]

Definition.Title: MCQ: Living or Non-Living? 2
Definition.TextTemplate:
[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/German/1448489398.975111g/1448489408805-4431982697943419.png" width="230" height="291"][image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1463605004.58361g/1463605005509-1374833454052553.png" width="200" height="328"]

The robot above carries out **some** of the eight processes in **@@228B22@MRS C GREN,**@@ but **not all of them. **

Is the robot **@@228B22@living**@@ or **@@7C0BAE@non-living?**@@

[multichoice id="MultiChoice_1"]
Definition.ExplanationTemplate: If something carries out some but not all of the eight life processes described by MRS C GREN, it is classified as @@7C0BAE@**non-living**. @@

Definition.Title: MCQ: Living or Non-Living? 1
Definition.TextTemplate:
[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/German/1479701061.546371g/1479701065158-2884967761454731.jpg" width="400" height="267"][image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1463605004.58361g/1463605005509-1374833454052553.png" width="200" height="328"]

Cows carry out @@0066cc@**all**@@ of the eight processes in **@@228B22@MRS C GREN.**@@

Is the cow **@@228B22@living**@@ or **@@7C0BAE@non-living?**@@

[multichoice id="MultiChoice_1"]
Definition.ExplanationTemplate: If something carries out all of the eight life processes described by MRS C GREN, it is classified as **@@228B22@living.@@**

Definition.Title: MCQ: Living or Non-Living? 3
Definition.TextTemplate:
[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1446607220.028781g/1446607220911-656435869127058.png" width="444" height="258"][image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1463605004.58361g/1463605005509-1374833454052553.png" width="200" height="328"]

Mould carries out @@0066cc@**all**@@ of the eight processes in **@@228B22@MRS C GREN.**@@

Is mould **@@228B22@living**@@ or **@@7C0BAE@non-living?**@@

[multichoice id="MultiChoice_1"]
Definition.ExplanationTemplate: If something carries out all of the eight life processes described by MRS C GREN, it is classified as **@@228B22@living.@@** Some things that you’d never think of can still be living!

Definition.TextTemplate:
[fill-gaps id="FillInTheGaps_2"]

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1498175822.195071g/1498175837719-82439342338564.jpg" width="280" height="315"]

[table border="no" 
| align="center" width=70 | **M**: || width=30 | || width=550|  All or part of a living thing is able to [2: move].
=
| **R**:  || || Stands for [3: respiration]: this is how living things turn food and air into energy.  
=

=
| **C**: || || Living things are made up of cells.
]

Definition.TextTemplate:
[fill-gaps id="FillInTheGaps_2"]

=

=

=
|**R**:|| || Living things can [1: reproduce], and some can have many offspring.
=

Definition.Title: MCQ: Life Processes 2
Definition.TextTemplate:
What is the@@0066cc@** acronym** @@for determining whether something is @@228B22@**living?**@@

[multichoice id="MultiChoice_1"]

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/German/1466565190.844661g/1466565211036-4308602489656775.jpg" width="300" height="199"]
Definition.ExplanationTemplate:
The acronym we use for determining whether something is living or not living is @@228B22@**MRS C GREN. **@@

[table border="no"
| width=100 align="center" | **M** || width=400 | Movement
=
| **R** || Respiration 
=
| **S** || Sensitivity (feeling)
=
| **C** || Cells
=
| **G** || Growth
=
| **R** || Reproduction (producing offspring)
=
| **E** || Excretion (pooping) 
=
| **N** || Nutrition (eating) 
]

Definition.Title: MCQ: Life Processes 3
Definition.TextTemplate:
**True or false?**

"There are **@@fb6611@five features@@** that things **need to have** for them to be **@@228B22@living.@@**"

[multichoice id="MultiChoice_1"]

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1499380776.022221g/1499380784058-3751245520565656.jpg" width="300" height="200"]
Definition.ExplanationTemplate:
**This is false!**

There are **@@0066cc@eight features@@** that things need to have for them to be **@@228B22@living!@@**

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1463605004.58361g/1463605005509-1374833454052553.png"]

Definition.Title: Introduction: Living and Non-living Things 2
Definition.TextTemplate:
Our planet is also full of things that **@@7C0BAE@aren’t living.@@** 

**Rocks, water **and even the **chair** you are sitting on are all @@7C0BAE@**non-living things! **@@

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/English & Literature/1497498277.04271f/1497498280498-2401000824806999.gif"]

Definition.Title: Introduction: Living and Non-living Things 4
Definition.TextTemplate:
To determine whether a thing is **@@228B22@living@@** or **@@7C0BAE@non-living,@@** we can look at some of its **characteristics** or **features**. 

There are **@@0066cc@eight features@@** that things need to have for them to be **@@228B22@living.@@** Living things must have @@0066cc@**ALL**@@ of these features, otherwise they are @@7C0BAE@**not living!**@@

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1492057255.066181f/1492057274093-1094795692863087.gif" width="400" height="225" ]

Definition.Title: Introduction: Living and Non-living Things 5
Definition.TextTemplate:
We can remember these **@@0066cc@eight features@@** by using the acronym:

@@228B22@**MRS C GREN. **@@

[table border="no"
| width=100 align="center" | **M** || width=400 | Movement
=
| **R** || Respiration 
=
| **S** || Sensitivity 
=
| **C** || Cells
=
| **G** || Growth
=
| **R** || Reproduction 
=
| **E** || Excretion  
=
| **N** || Nutrition 
]

As a@@228B22@** living**@@ thing, you do (or are capable of doing) @@0066cc@**all of these things!** @@A@@7C0BAE@** non-living**@@ thing, on the other hand, **is not. ** We will look more into @@228B22@**MRS C GREN**@@ in the next section!

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/German/1465684180.087441g/1465684190987-515078079353522.png" width="400" height="244"]

Definition.Title: Introduction: Movement 1
Definition.TextTemplate:
[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1501459130.230151g/1501459139358-4314669790847519.png" width="700" height="70"]

**Movement**

The first letter in **@@228B22@MRS C GREN,@@** ‘M’, stands for **Movement.** 

All living things **@@fb6611@move.@@** Animals use **@@00a6d5@structures@@** like legs or wings to help them move. 

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1499037205.940511g/1499037209470-4026138609402080.jpg" width="399" height="222"]

Definition.Title: Introduction: Movement 2
Definition.TextTemplate:
What about **@@228B22@plants?@@** They don’t move...do they? How come they’re a @@228B22@**living thing? **@@

Actually, plants move too! They may not move their **@@00a6d5@whole bodies@@** (like animals do), but they can move **@@fb6611@parts@@** of themselves, like when they move their leaves to @@fb6611@**face the sun! **@@

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1499037950.187721f/1499037951383-4026138609402080.gif" width="376" height="300"]

Definition.Title: Introduction: Respiration
Definition.TextTemplate:
[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1501459130.230151g/1501459139358-4314669790847519.png" width="700" height="70"]

**Respiration**

We all need **@@fb6611@energy@@** to live, and **respiration** is what helps us get it. 

Respiration converts the **@@228B22@food@@** we eat and the **@@228B22@air@@** we breathe into @@fb6611@**energy! **@@

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Maths/1491947258.645561g/1491947264601-3815586246930701.png" width="300" height="141"]

Definition.Title: Introduction: Sensitivity
Definition.TextTemplate:
[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1501459130.230151g/1501459139358-4314669790847519.png" width="700" height="70"]

**Sensitivity

All **@@228B22@living things@@** are @@0066cc@**sensitive**@@ to the environment around them. 

Humans have@@0066cc@ **five main senses:** @@sight, hearing, taste, smell and touch. 

If you touch a **@@fb6611@hot stove,@@** or a naughty kitten **@@fb6611@claws your hand,@@** you feel **@@228B22@pain@@** - this is what it means to be @@0066cc@**sensitive! **@@

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1448912933.74511g/1448912950225-491954455224470.jpg" width="300" height="359"]

Definition.Title: Introduction: Growth
Definition.TextTemplate:
[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1501459130.230151g/1501459139358-4314669790847519.png" width="700" height="70"]

**Growth** 

All **@@228B22@living things@@** **grow** as they get older. 

If they didn’t, dogs would be puppies, trees would be seeds and you would be a baby for @@00a6d5@**your entire life! **@@

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Maths/1478485470.852391f/1478485474535-1148204681684949.gif" width="390" height="215"]

Definition.Title: Introduction: Reproduction
Definition.TextTemplate:
[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1501459130.230151g/1501459139358-4314669790847519.png" width="700" height="70"]

**Reproduction

All @@228B22@**living things**@@ are capable of **reproduction. **

Reproduction means that living things can produce **@@00a6d5@offspring,@@** or babies. You are the offspring of your parents, which means they **@@0066cc@reproduced@@** to make you! 

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/German/1480638358.950621g/1480638375419-2792827041847147.jpg" width="340" height="227"]

Definition.Title: Introduction: Excretion
Definition.TextTemplate:
[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1501459130.230151g/1501459139358-4314669790847519.png" width="700" height="70"]
**Excretion

**Excretion** is the **@@fb6611@removal of waste products@@** from the body. 

We humans do this every time we visit the **@@0066cc@toilet,@@** otherwise known as peeing and pooping. 

Every time we @@228B22@**breathe out,**@@ we remove the waste product **carbon dioxide** from our bodies. This is also** excretion!**

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1458099235.370411g/1458099235756-761434393700316.png" width="160" height="239"]

Definition.Title: Introduction: Nutrition
Definition.TextTemplate:
[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1501459130.230151g/1501459139358-4314669790847519.png" width="700" height="70"]

**Nutrition

 **@@0066cc@Food@@** is amazing, but have you ever thought about **@@228B22@why@@** we eat it? 

Living things need **@@fb6611@energy@@** to grow and move. As animals, we gain this energy by @@0066cc@**eating food.** @@Other **@@228B22@living things@@** obtain it in **other ways. **

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1499116207.517871f/1499116211645-4419156850218960.gif" width="300" height="215"]

Definition.Title: Long Answer: Fire
Definition.TextTemplate:
[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Maths/1489382898.984021f/1489382902034-1240436008403428.gif" width="350" height="175"]

Is fire a **@@228B22@living thing@@** or a@@7C0BAE@ **non-living thing?**@@

Use **@@228B22@MRS C GREN@@** to **explain** your answer. 

//Feel free to do some research on the internet to help you answer this question!//

[long-answer id="LongAnswer_1"]

Options.Text: Fire is/is not a living thing because...

Components.ModelAnswerHTML:
Fire is able to move, and it can also reproduce (because a spark of fire can travel to a different location and start another fire). Fire seems to carry out nutrition, since it requires fuel. It also grows larger as it consumes more fuel. Fire also carries out something similar to excretion, because it releases a gas when it burns.

However, fire cannot feel things, does not have cells and it does not carry out respiration.

Therefore, fire is not a living thing, because it does not carry out all seven of the processes described by MRS C GREN.

Definition.TextTemplate:
Awesome work! You've finished this lesson on **@@00a6d5@Living and Non-living Things!**@@

=

]

Definition.Title: Summary: Living and Non-living Things 2
Definition.TextTemplate:
There are **@@228B22@eight features@@** that things need to have for them to be **@@228B22@living.@@** 

Living things must have **ALL** of these features, otherwise they are @@7C0BAE@**not living.**@@

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1482186377.81211g/1482186384408-2132871752100020.jpg" width="350" height="196"]

Definition.Title: Summary: Living and Non-living Things 3
Definition.TextTemplate:
We can remember these **@@228B22@eight features@@** by using the acronym:

@@228B22@**MRS C GREN. **@@

[table border="no"
| width=100 align="center" | **M** || width=400 | Movement
=
| **R** || Respiration 
=
| **S** || Sensitivity (feeling)
=
| **C** || Cells
=
| **G** || Growth
=
| **R** || Reproduction (producing offspring)
=
| **E** || Excretion (pooping) 
=
| **N** || Nutrition (eating) 
]

As a living thing, you do (or are capable of doing) @@4@**all of these things!** 

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1501459130.230151g/1501459139358-4314669790847519.png" width="700" height="70"]

Definition.Title: Introduction: Living and Non-living Things 3
Definition.TextTemplate:
But **@@00a6d5@how@@** do we know what is@@228B22@ **living** @@and @@7C0BAE@**non-living? **@@In this Smart Lesson, you will learn the answer! 

By the end of the lesson, you should be able to **answer** the following @@0066cc@**questions: **@@

[table border="no" 
| `1.` || What is the difference between a **@@228B22@living@@** and a **@@7C0BAE@non-living@@** thing?
=
| `2.` || What does **@@228B22@MRS C GREN@@** stand for?
] 

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/German/1480021835.56251g/1480021854227-767455438135480.jpg" width="400" height="284"]

Definition.Title: Introduction: Cells
Definition.TextTemplate:
[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/Science/1501459130.230151g/1501459139358-4314669790847519.png" width="700" height="70"]

**Cells **

Every@@228B22@** living thing**@@ is made up of @@7C0BAE@**cells!**@@

[image url="https://www.languageperfect.com/media/content/German/1469662582.813781g/1469662605545-587583545146450.jpg" width="400" height="267"]
